It was covered here, although not in a news story, you're right: 

No Glory (Satellite) in Space - http://nyti.ms/gBNYLN

Not a SINGLE article on the loss of NASA's Glory last Friday: we have to learn the details from the BBC. This failure is a terrible blow: the information we would have learned from Glory is desperately needed to further quantify the magnitude of the radiative effects of atmospheric aerosols.

The failure is especially significant because the last NASA Earth Science mission launch, the OCO, also failed -- and for the same reason (the fairing failed to separate). Unbelievable! Is someone sabotaging these launches or have we just gotten incompetent; or incredibly unlucky? And on top of this, two important future climate missions have been scrapped (CLARREO and DESDynI). What happened to President Obama's promises to support science? Did the budget all go to the NIH?

Is anyone at the NYT paying attention? Let me answer that: "Why not?" The Beeb has a guy on all aspects of space -- including Earth Observation -- full time. And here is another interesting article from the BBC.

Please get it together NYT: sack that muppet John Tierney and get some real science journalism in here -- or is that asking too much of a major national US daily?

Now let me read the blog post....

It was covered here, although not in a news story, you're right: 

No Glory (Satellite) in Space - http://nyti.ms/gBNYLN

Please: do not EVER use the phrase "ground truthing" w.r.t satellite imaging. There is no absolute truth, only estimates with associated uncertainties. Bona fide remote sensing scientists should use "ground reference data", or "field measurements", or something similar: never a phrase with "truth" in it. Too pedantic? Not at all: science requires precision in the language used to communicate, or the meaning can become fuzzy. Science needs both sharp minds and sharp language skills.

Otherwise a good post, if a little on the minimal side, considering the significance of this discipline for multiple areas of human enterprise (agriculture, meteo, military, ecology, climate, oceanography, hydrology... and a bazillion others). As I mentioned in the other post, Auntie Beeb has a guy on this stuff full time, posting a new story almost every day. Europe/Japan are racing ahead while our capability is diminished: it's an appalling story from the nation that sent people to the Moon... in 1969.

Great article David, I always enjoy your perspective on our tech world. However I am amazed at the rise of love/hate opinions about the iPad, which seem worse than the opinions blasted about the iPhone, which were heated at times. I think both Google and Apple make great products, which is great for consumers. Competition keeps the pressure on them to continue to improve their devices/software.

The interesting thing that fascinates me is that Apple entered the virgin tablet market with a great product, but did not overprice the iPad with a 'premium' price but rather a low entry price point that stunned consumers and their competition. I believe that this was the one detail that delayed the competition from going head to head with the iPad. Now Apple has the 2nd gen iPad ready to go, and Honeycomb is still in its arrival and priced way over the iPad. Combining this with the eco-system of the app store, retail stores with helpful and savvy customer service, and it appears to be 'game over' for the competitors. I think that Apple was not content to make a great product and have it separate itself from other tablets just on form and function alone; they have that business model down to a science. No, they upped the ante by making a great product, selling it and entrenching it for over a year before any others arrived, and undercutting the one real advantage its competitors have used against Apple over the years.....the price.

I want one, and I'm saving my pennies now! I like Apple products and I know a winner when I see one. Now I can also afford it, which makes me very happy!
For reference, THIS AP paragraph is what NYT readers got on the Glory story. Compare this, gentle reader, with the BBC article.

I see both side complicit in inaction. The Dems are just being dumb by not directly addressing the economic issues with climate change and fossil fuel dependency. They continue to look like the stereotype of a tax and spend liberal who cant be bothered with economic cost.

The republicans are making the economic issue primary because its an easy sell and fits their stereotype. A lingering recession makes this easy.

A strong economic case needs to be made and it sounds like the scientists are beginning to make the basis for that case. We are getting past the sweeping "catastrophic" climate change statements and getting down to the reality of climate change impacts on the economy.

I thought the anchor analogy was brilliant when applied to crop yields. We wont starve tomorrow but it makes every farmers job harder and that effects us all economically.

I know its popular to vilify the "other" side of the aisle on climate change but it's clearly both sides contributing to the problem of inaction.

So, we lose faith in our government to address energy change.

The question now is what's next. How can we, as a people, join the people of the wide world to affect change and mitigate the damage that our children & grandchildren will face?

I believe we face an era where we need to turn our attention and energy away from our grinding-to-a-halt government and towards our best interests.

This is not a knock on the heroic efforts of good-hearted on all sides who are in the trenches in government - my prayers go out for them and their work.

It is rather a practical call to "get it done" re our future.

Robert Leming
Philadelphia

Here is Andy: "Whatever you think about the risks posed by human-generated greenhouse gases, warming on time scales relevant to climate is clear, as are the basic properties of these gases. There's plenty of room for discussion ..." Sorry, Andy, you have to distinguish between the basic physical properties of a gas and its behavior in the atmosphere. The basic properties of these gases are not in question. What is in question is how they behave in the atmosphere. Global warming cannot happen if these gases are not actually blocking the infrared radiation that is leaving the earth despite their presence in the atmosphere. It so happens that Ferenc Miskolczy, using NOAA database of weather ballo;n observations that goes back to 1948, has demonstrated that "...the global average annual infrared thickness of the atmosphere has been unchanged for 61 years, with a value of 1.87. It will be inferred that CO2 does not affect the climate through the greenhouse effect." As far as I am concerned, this is correct  As I pointed out the satellite record shows that within the last 31 years there was only one short spurt of global warmiing, non-anthropogenic, and no other warming if you don't include Arctic warming. Arctic warming is actually the only real warming that is happening now and its cause is warm Atlantic currents invading the Arctic and not CO2 as  loudly touted by warming advocates. Miskolczi's result is purely empirical and overrides any calculations from theory. Theory that yields a different result must either be adjusted or abandoned. I want to point out also that his,work appeared at the end of 2009. No one has attempted to publish any peer reviewed contrary claims since then.

This isn't worth getting excited about. China, India and the rest of the rapidly developing world will continue to increase their carbon emissions, rapidly. We are insignificant and a hypothetical 10% reduction in our carbon emission would be an insignificant fraction of insignificance.

So, don't fight about the science. Maybe warming will be bad for us, maybe it will be good, maybe it won't matter. We'll find out, empirically, in a generation or two, whatever we do. What we conclude and what Congress legislates won't change it.

However many facts we have, indeed the more facts we have, the easier it is today for someone to deny things that are simply undeniable—and pull a whole debate into a sinkhole. Our inability, or unwillingness to take someone with no regard for the facts out of the debate strikes me as a tragedy of our times.

There are many people in northern Sudan with no regard for the facts. These pictures make it harder for them to drag us into their sinkhole.

8. HIGHLIGHT by Mark, Dallas:
"I'll say it again, it's not about the past or the future, it's about today. Forget the tree rings, ice cores and models. If we go to work now, what are the benefits of a national effort to reduce greenhouse gasses? What are the economic risks of doing nothing?" Apparently he wants to discount science (those tree rings, ice cores, and models) and start reducing greenhouse gases right now. And then he wants to know what are the benefits of doing so and what are the risks of doing nothing. It is not clear to me on what basis he wants to reduce greenhouse gases if he does not want to bother with science. But as long as he is asking for answers, here they are: benefit of reducing greenhouse gases: nil. That is because there is no global warming they are supposed to cause. And economic risks of doing nothing? Nil, and for the same reason. I recommend that he should attempt to inform himself about real climate science before he comes out with any more brilliant ideas and spring for "What Warming?" available on Amazon right now.
